Issues.Title: fix(router): prevent calling unsubscribe on undefined subscription in RouterPreloader
Issues.Body:
Previously, the `ngOnDestroy` method called `unsubscribe` regardless of if `subscription` had
been initialized.  This can lead to an error attempting to call `unsubscribe` of undefined.
This change prevents this error, and instead only attempts `unsubscribe` when the subscription
has been defined.

Issues.Title: BrowserAnimationsModule not working properly with scrollPositionRestoration
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report

### Affected Package
This is possibly caused by the `BrowserAnimationsModule` from `@angular/platform-browser/animations`
### Description
Scroll position is not restoring properly when `BrowserAnimationsModule` is used in the project.
See the demo reproduction. Try commenting the `BrowserAnimationsModule` to see the difference.

## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-c4pgqm
Please note to see the scroll behaviour you need to open the stackblitz preview in a separate tab: https://angular-ivy-c4pgqm.stackblitz.io

### `BrowserAnimationsModule` enabled (results in incorrect behaviour :x: )
```ts
@NgModule({
  imports:      [ AppRoutingModule, BrowserModule, BrowserAnimationsModule], // <-- here
  declarations: [ AppComponent ],
  bootstrap:    [ AppComponent ]
})
export class AppModule { }
```
(incorrect behaviour demo)
![Peek 2020-08-04 16-52](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12165822/89288972-1da31980-d674-11ea-89f8-aca53a80fcc4.gif)

Sometimes it behaves correctly and sometimes it won't.

### `BrowserAnimationsModule` disabled (working properly :heavy_check_mark: )
```ts
@NgModule({
  imports:      [ AppRoutingModule, BrowserModule, /*BrowserAnimationsModule*/], // <-- here
  declarations: [ AppComponent ],
  bootstrap:    [ AppComponent ]
})
export class AppModule { }
```
Note that scroll position is retained here correctly when coming back to the route.
(expected behaviour)
![Peek 2020-08-04 16-55](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12165822/89289297-a02bd900-d674-11ea-9181-d126391a1173.gif)

Issues.Title: Incorrect docs example of providers as acceptable selectors for the @ViewChild decorator
Issues.Body: # 📚 Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description [This PR](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38264) (#38264) was merged on July 28. In it, a change removing an example of **a service class as a provider-token selector for the ViewChild decorator** was made. The author of the change wrote in the PR description that: > `@ViewChild` doesn't work on service. However, the documentation says @ViewChild(SomeService) The `@ViewChild` decorator does query services classes configured as providers tokens in child components. [Here's an example](https://stackblitz.com/edit/view-child-service-provider-selector). The change was to the example of the third entry of acceptable selectors for `@ViewChild`. https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/ff9f4de4f1147ba9ea6d17c31442a2eedcf4e0d2/packages/core/src/metadata/di.ts#L334-L335 In the change above, `SomeComponent` is not a provider but a component. The example given is more in line with the first entry of acceptable selectors (`@Component`). https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/ff9f4de4f1147ba9ea6d17c31442a2eedcf4e0d2/packages/core/src/metadata/di.ts#L330-L331 I believe this should be reverted back to what it was originally. https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/1d844b9bd8140953487f291e352ff55656154b41/packages/core/src/metadata/di.ts#L334-L335 ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction This isn't exactly a reproduction but an example to show that you can query service class providers using the `@ViewChild` decorator. https://stackblitz.com/edit/view-child-service-provider-selector ### What's the affected URL? https://angular.io/api/core/ViewChild ## 📷Screenshot ## 🔥 Exception or Error No error. ## 🌍 Your Environment ``` Angular CLI: 10.0.4 Node: 12.9.0 OS: darwin x64 Angular: 10.0.7 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic ... router Ivy Workspace: Yes Package Version ----------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1000.4 @angular-devkit/build-angular 0.1000.4 @angular-devkit/build-optimizer 0.1000.4 @angular-devkit/build-webpack 0.1000.4 @angular-devkit/core 10.0.4 @angular-devkit/schematics 10.0.4 @angular/cli 10.0.4 @ngtools/webpack 10.0.4 @schematics/angular 10.0.4 @schematics/update 0.1000.4 rxjs 6.5.5 typescript 3.9.7 webpack 4.43.0 ```

Issues.Title: Mark eager `NgModuleFactory` construction as not side effectful
Issues.Body:
Roll forward of #38147.

This allows Closure compiler to tree shake unused constructor calls to `NgModuleFactory`, which is otherwise considered
side-effectful. The Angular compiler generates factory objects which are exported but typically not used, as they are
only needed for compatibility with View Engine. This results in top-level constructor calls, such as:

```typescript
export const FooNgFactory = new NgModuleFactory(Foo);
```

`NgModuleFactory` has a side-effecting constructor, so this statement cannot be tree shaken, even if `FooNgFactory` is
never imported. The `NgModuleFactory` continues to reference its associated `NgModule` and prevents the module and all
its unused dependencies from being tree shaken, making Closure builds significantly larger than necessary.

The fix here is to wrap `NgModuleFactory` constructor with `noSideEffects(() => /* ... */)`, which tricks the Closure
compiler into assuming that the invoked function has no side effects. This allows it to tree-shake unused
`NgModuleFactory()` constructors when they aren't imported. Since the factory can be removed, the module can also be
removed (if nothing else references it), thus tree shaking unused dependencies as expected.

The one notable edge case is for lazy loaded modules. Internally, lazy loading is done as a side effect when the lazy
script is evaluated. For Angular, this side effect is registering the `NgModule`. In Ivy this is done by the
`NgModuleFactory` constructor, so lazy loaded modules **cannot** have their top-level `NgModuleFactory` constructor
call tree shaken. We handle this case by looking for the `id` field on `@NgModule` annotations. All lazy loaded modules
include an `id`. When this `id` is found, the `NgModuleFactory` is generated **without** with `noSideEffects()` call,
so Closure will not tree shake it and the module will lazy-load correctly.

Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [X ] build ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.x ### Description I have an Angular library that I've been trying to update to Angular 10.x. I've noticed that, even without making ANY changes to the library code, it will randomly build differently. I can build it 10 times in a row without making any changes to the code and approximately 50% of the time (or more), it will build in such a way that causes a client application to fail to build. It's important to note that the library itself always appears to build successfully - it produces no noticeable errors. I'm using the "--prod" flag every time to build it with the View engine instead of Ivy. However, the code only works when the dist build includes an "__ivy_ngcc__" directory and a file that ends with ".__ivy_ngcc_bak". There may be other differences in the dist contents as well, but those are the ones that immediately stand out. If the build process fails to produce output that contains those 2 items, then an Angular app that consumes the library fails to build. The consuming application produces errors that say: `ERROR in The target entry-point "[library name]" has missing dependencies:` followed by a long list of items (services, pipes, interfaces, etc.) from the library that it thinks are "missing". I can resolve this by simply rebuilding the library, then the client app several times until the library contains the "ivy_ngcc" items mentioned above - at which point the client app that consumes the library will build successfully. Again... it is my understanding that the "--prod" flag makes the code build with View, not Ivy. So I'm not sure why it ever produces the "ivy_ngcc" items and I'm not sure why it only works when they are present. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Unfortunately, my library is almost 100% proprietary code so I can make it publicly available for testing. However, I can describe the approach that I've taken: 1) I built a brand new workspace, per the Angular library documentation 2) I added a library to the workspace and added a large number of items (services, etc.), contained in about 6 modules. 3) I added a test application to the workspace, which references the library (directly via filesystem reference - not through NPM yet) 4) I'm simply repeating the following commands to test: `ng build my-lib --prod` `ng build my-app` ## 🌍 Your Environment

Issues.Title: fix(material/progress-spinner): Progress spinner animation fails for floating point diameter values
Issues.Body:
The spinner diameter is used in the `animation-name` CSS property for the indeterminate spinner `circle` element. If the diameter is a floating point value the animation name will include a period ‘.’ character e.g. `animation-name-90.6`. Period characters are not supported for the animation-name property - see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/animation-name.

Replacing the period character in the diameter string with an underscore fixes this issue e.g. `animation-name-90_6`

Fixes #20158
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/progress-spinner): Progress spinner animation fails for floating point diameter values" (#20192)

Issues.Title: feat(button-toggle): Add support for radio-button interaction pattern
Issues.Body:
`MatButtonToggle` and `MatButtonToggleGroup` previously use either a native checkbox or a radio button depending on whether the control had multiple selection. We changed this to always using a native `<button>` element with `aria-pressed` partially based on this [article by Heydon Pickering](https://inclusive-components.design/toggle-button).

I was recently given some feedback from a from a screen-reader user that, while `button[aria-pressed]` and checkbox are effectively interchangeable, using the radio-button interaction pattern is preferable for single-selection in a lot of cases. As such, we should re-add support for the radio-button pattern. I'm imagining we can do this similarly to how we support multiple interaction pattern in other components (e.g. list, chips) via selector, potentially something like
```html
<mat-button-toggle-radio-group aria-label="Text alignment">
  <mat-button-toggle-radio>Left</mat-button-toggle-radio>
  <mat-button-toggle-radio>Center</mat-button-toggle-radio>
  <mat-button-toggle-radio>Right</mat-button-toggle-radio>
</mat-button-toggle-radio-group>
```

This variant should use a native `<input type="radio">` in its template so that we get the correct keyboard interaction for free.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(button-toggle): Add support for radio-button interaction pattern" (#20190)

Issues.Title: refactor(cdk-experimental/dialog): sync with recent material dialog changes
Issues.Body:
We recently landed the MDC-based dialog. For this one, we changed
how the dialog initializes the focus trap, saves the previously
focused element, focuses the dialog container.

Previously, all of this this has been performed before the content
has been attached. The dialog used `Promise.resolve` to wait for
the content to be attached. This has been cleaned up now so that the
container is initialized properly (without the `Promise.resolve` trick)
after the content has been attached.

We initially did this in the MDC-based dialog PR through the
`ngAfterViewInit` lifecycle hook, but that unveiled issues
in g3 where the focus is moved too early to the container. We
fixed this in the Material dialog by having an explicit
`_initializeWithAttachedContent` method on the container.

The change has just not been applied to the CDK dialog. This
commit syncs the CDK dialog with the latest changes.
